0.text: Emotional exhaustion is often the result of prolonged stress and a lack of resources for recovery. Regular breaks, hobbies, and support from family and friends can significantly help in combating this condition.
0.fact: In a Gallup survey of employees, it was found that 23% of respondents experience burnout always or very often, while another 44% experience it sometimes.

1.text: Physical activity and proper nutrition play a key role in maintaining energy levels and preventing feelings of fatigue.
1.fact: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, has repeatedly spoken about the importance of proper rest and sleep for maintaining productivity and preventing fatigue. He claims that a minimum of eight hours of sleep per day helps him stay energetic and effective.

2.text: Planning morning time can help reduce stress and increase motivation. Rituals such as exercise, meditation, or reading can make the morning more pleasant.
2.fact: Tim Cook, the CEO of Apple, is known for his early rising (around 4:30 AM). Nevertheless, he emphasizes the importance of a good night's sleep and regular physical exercise for maintaining energy and motivation.

3.text: Training in emotional intelligence development can help managers and employees better understand each other and work more effectively. This may include courses in active listening, conflict management, and empathy development.
3.fact: Emotional intelligence (EQ) plays a key role in team management and workplace success. Studies show that 90% of top performers have a high level of emotional intelligence, according to data from TalentSmart.

4.text: Empathy and personal attention from leadership can significantly reduce employee turnover. A study conducted by Harvard Business Review showed that employees who feel supported and valued by their managers are 4 times less likely to leave the company.
4.fact: Elon Musk, the founder of Tesla and SpaceX, is known for his demanding nature and intensity. Some employees have noted that his management style can be harsh and lacking in personal approach, which has led to stress and burnout among the team.

5.text: Psychological practices such as meditation, yoga, and mindfulness techniques can help maintain emotional balance and increase energy levels.
5.fact: Richard Branson, the founder of Virgin Group, is known for his enthusiasm and energy. He often emphasizes the importance of a positive attitude and energy for achieving success in both business and personal life. Branson claims that a positive attitude helps him overcome difficulties and inspire his team.

6.text: Conflict management training may include developing skills in active listening, empathy, and the ability to find compromises. Courses and trainings on these topics can be very beneficial for employees at all levels.
6.fact: Effective conflict resolution can significantly increase team productivity. A Harvard Business Review study showed that companies that successfully manage conflicts have 30% higher productivity.

7.text: Psychotherapy and counseling with a psychologist can be very helpful for those experiencing depression and apathy. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is often used to treat depression and burnout.

8.text: Feedback and recognition from colleagues and management can strengthen confidence in the significance of one's work. Regular recognition of employee achievements contributes to increasing their motivation and satisfaction.
8.fact: Job satisfaction is linked to improved productivity. According to Harvard Business Review data, employees who see the value in their work are 21% more productive and 22% more profitable for the company.

9.text: Neuroscience research has shown that when people show empathy, their brain activates the same areas as during physical pain. This means that emotional connection can indeed be deep and meaningful.
9.fact: Ray Dalio, the founder of Bridgewater Associates, is known for his philosophy of "radical transparency" and honesty in the workplace. He believes that open discussion of problems and mistakes helps improve team relationships and increase its effectiveness.

10.text: Studies show that maintaining a work-life balance can significantly reduce stress levels and prevent bitterness. Companies like Basecamp actively promote short work weeks and minimizing overtime to improve employee well-being.
10.fact: Martin Seligman's work on positive psychology shows that developing traits such as gratitude and optimism can significantly improve emotional state and reduce bitterness.

11.text: Research in positive psychology, such as the work of Martin Seligman, shows that optimism and belief in the future can significantly improve quality of life and contribute to achieving goals.
11.fact: In some countries, such as Sweden, there is a concept of "fika" - a mandatory break for coffee and communication, which helps reduce stress and prevent burnout.

12.text: Immersing oneself in hobbies or personal projects can provide a sense of satisfaction and balance out negative emotions associated with work. Well-known businessmen, such as Richard Branson, actively engage in various personal projects that bring them joy and inspiration.

13.text: Jack Ma, the founder of a major internet company, was once an advocate of the "996" work model (9 AM to 9 PM, 6 days a week). However, he later acknowledged that such a work regime could be harmful to the health of employees and the organization as a whole.

14.text: Studies show that burnout can be "contagious" in work collectives, spreading from one employee to another.

15.text: The concept of "digital detox" - a period of complete disconnection from electronic devices - is becoming increasingly popular as a way to combat information overload and burnout.
15.fact: Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, is known for his long periods of vacation and disconnection from social networks. He believes that such breaks help him maintain energy and inspiration for work.

16.text: The concept of "psychological safety" in teams was developed by Harvard Business School professor Amy Edmondson. She claims that this is a key factor in team effectiveness.
16.fact: According to the Society for Human Resource Management, 61% of employees consider trust between workers and management very important for job satisfaction.

17.text: The concept of "flow", described by psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, explains a state of complete immersion in an activity, accompanied by a feeling of energy and pleasure.
17.fact: Google uses the "20% time" rule, allowing employees to spend a fifth of their work time on projects of their own choice, which increases creativity and engagement.

18.text: According to the Pew Research Center, 30% of Americans view their work as a calling, 44% as a career, and 24% simply as a way to earn a living.
18.fact: TOMS Shoes uses the "One for One" model, where for every pair of shoes sold, they donate a pair to those in need, giving employees a sense that their work brings real benefit.

19.text: The concept of "ikigai" in Japanese culture describes the intersection of what you love, what you're good at, what the world needs, and what you can be paid for. This is considered the key to job satisfaction.
19.fact: Muhammad Yunus, a Nobel Peace Prize laureate, founded Grameen Bank to provide microcredit to the poor. He often speaks about the importance of creating "social business" to solve world problems.

20.text: In Sweden, some companies are experimenting with a 6-hour workday to increase productivity and reduce burnout. Preliminary results show an increase in employee energy and motivation.
20.fact: Oprah Winfrey admitted in 2008 that she experienced burnout and loss of interest in her show, which led to the decision to end it several years later.

21.text: Google offers its employees a course called "Search Inside Yourself", which teaches mindfulness and emotional intelligence skills for better stress and emotion management at work.
21.fact: According to the World Health Organization, depression and anxiety cost the global economy $1 trillion a year in lost productivity.

22.text: The term "emotional vampirism" in psychology describes people who drain the energy of those around them, often by offloading their problems onto others.
22.fact: Some companies, such as Zappos, are implementing a system of "holacracy" - a management model where responsibility is distributed among self-organizing teams rather than concentrated on managers.

low.text: Your productivity is at a fairly high level. Although you may feel tired from time to time, your overall condition remains within the norm. You seem to have found a golden mean between work and rest, which helps you maintain harmony and energy. Keep it up!
low.title: High productivity

middle.text: Your productivity has slightly decreased, and it seems that the balance of your life has shifted towards work. At this stage, it is not critical – you still enjoy your work and maintain sufficient productivity. However, it is worth paying attention to improving the balance between rest and work to maintain high efficiency and well-being in the long run.
middle.title: Reduced productivity

hight.text: Your internal resources are on the verge of exhaustion. Perhaps you are significantly overworking or engaging in activities that you do not enjoy. This state can last quite a long time, but productivity and job satisfaction will gradually decrease. To maintain your health and efficiency, it is important to review your approach to balancing work and rest as soon as possible. Find time to recover and allow yourself to rest to regain energy and motivation.
hight.title: Close to burnout

text: Do you often feel tired and unwilling to go to work?
Take our test to find out if you have signs of burnout. Decreased productivity and job satisfaction are often related to overworking.
This test will determine your current level of productivity and suggest whether you should reconsider the balance between work and rest.
